titleStmt.title: Event-Based Consensus for Linear Multiagent Systems Without Continuous Communication

analytic.title: Event-Based Consensus for Linear Multiagent Systems Without Continuous Communication

biblStruct.note: received May 19, 2016; revised August 1, 2016; accepted September 12, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we propose a new distributed event-trigger consensus protocol for linear multiagent systems with external disturbances. Two consensus problems are considered: one is a leader-follower case and the other is a nonleader case. Different from the existing results, our proposed scheme enables each agent to decide when to transmit its state signals to its neighbors such that continuous communication between neighboring agents is avoided. Clearly, this can largely decrease the communication burden of the whole communication network. Besides, since the control signal for each agent is discontinuous because of the event-triggering mechanism, the existence of a solution for the closed-loop system in the classical sense may not be guaranteed. To solve this problem, we employ a nonsmooth analysis technique including differential inclusion and Filippov solution. Through nonsmooth Lyapunov analysis, it is shown that uniformly bounded consensus results are derived and the bound of the consensus error is adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N RECENT years, distributed control has received a great deal of attention due to its potential applications in various areas, such as surveillance systems, satellite formation flying, electric power systems, intelligent transportation systems, etc. In the area of cooperative control, consensus is an important and fundamental research topic which aims to make a group of agents reach the same agreement by exchanging information only with their neighbors. Various consensus results can be found in [1]- [13] and references therein.

On the other hand, network control has also been actively researched as it has the advantages in improving control efficiency and reducing the maintenance cost. One key problem brought about by network control is how to address the communication constraints as a network only has limited resources. Compared with the traditional time-scheduled control approach, event-trigger control is an effective tool which aims to reduce the communication burden while ensuring satisfactory system performance. Actually, through careful research and comparisons, it is found that some ideas and approaches in event triggered systems are quite close to those employed in switched/impulsive systems a decade ago. For example, in [14], the system model and controller switching rule are very similar to the event triggering mechanism studied recently. Thus, it is also possible to employ the techniques used in switched/impulsive systems to address issues related to the event triggered systems. More details about event triggered systems and switched/impulsive systems can be found in [15]- [19], etc.

Nowadays, since each agent, such as a robot, is tending to be equipped with a microprocessor which has only limited resources, event-based consensus has become a hot research topic [20]. In [21], the problem of quantized iterative learning consensus tracking for digital networks with time-varying topologies is considered, while [22] investigates the iterative learning problem for multiple system nodes with event-triggered scheme and quantization. However, these two references only consider discrete-time linear systems. In [23] and [24], an event-trigger control strategy is proposed for a group of first-order agents. However, the proposed approach requires continuous communication between neighbors. In [25], an event-trigger control approach for both singleintegrator and double-integrator agents is proposed. Though continuous communication between neighbors is avoided, the communication graph is required to be undirected and the results cannot be extended to high-order systems. In [26], both the event-triggered and self-triggered consensus problems are studied for linear multiagent systems, but continuous communication is required in the event-triggered case and the communication graph is also undirected. In [27], two conditions with or without continuous communication between neighboring agents for linear multiagent systems are presented. However, the triggering event for each agent involves not only its own state signals, but also its neighbors' states as well as control signals. This makes the triggering mechanism complicated. Besides, possible external disturbance to each agent is not considered. More results about event triggered consensus can be found in [28]- [33] and references therein.
2168-2267 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

In this paper, we propose a new event-trigger consensus protocol for general linear multiagent systems. In contrast to the existing results, our proposed protocol has the following major advantages or novelties: first, each agent itself decides when to transmit its state signals to its neighbors such that continuous communication between neighboring agents is avoided. Moreover, each state of one agent can be transmitted to its neighbors asynchronously. This will largely decrease the communication burden. Additionally, since the closedloop system is discontinuous because of the event-triggering mechanism, the existence of a classical solution may not be guaranteed. So unlike the existing approaches which simply assume the existence of the classical solution, we adopt nonsmooth analysis techniques, including Filippov solution and differential inclusion, to analyze the closed-loop systems. Utilizing our proposed control protocol, two consensus problems for linear systems, namely, the leader-follower case and the nonleader case, are considered with external disturbances taking into consideration, and a high gain approach is proposed to compensate for the effects of the external disturbances on the final consensus error. Through Lyapunov analyses, it is shown that our proposed event-based protocol achieves uniformly bounded consensus, and the size of the consensus error bound is adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters.

The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes some mathematical preliminaries including graph theory and some background of nonsmooth analysis. Section III gives the system model, event triggering mechanism and control objective. Sections IV and V present the design and analysis of control protocols for the leader-follower case and nonleader case, respectively. Two simulation examples are presented in Section V to verify the established theoretical results. Finally, Section VI concludes this paper.

div.head: A. Notations
div.p: In this paper, we use the following notations: R n×m denotes n × m real matrix and I N denotes identity matrix of dimension N. 1 denotes a column vector of appropriate dimension with all its entries equal to one. A ⊗ B denotes the Kronecker product of matrices A and B.

div.head: B. Graph Theory
div.formula: A communication graph G = (V, E, A) contains a node set V = {1, . . . , N}, an edge set E ⊆ V × V and an adjacency matrix A = [a ij ] ∈ R N×N such that a ij > 0 if (j, i) ∈ E, and a ij = 0 if (j, i) / ∈ E.
div.p: For an edge (i, j), i is called the parent node while j is called the child node, and i is a neighbor of j. We assume no self-loop exist in this graph. The graph is called directed if an edge is an ordered pair of different vertices. Otherwise, it is called undirected. A directed path from vertices j to i is a list of ordered edges with j being the starting node and i is the ending node. A directed graph contains a spanning tree if there is a root vertex, which has no parent node, such that directed paths from this vertex to all the other vertex exist in the graph. The graph G is said to be strongly connected if for any i, j ∈ V there is an ordered path from i to j in G. A directed graph has a spanning tree if it is strongly connected, but not vice versa. L is called the Laplacian matrix of graph G satisfying L ii = i =j a ij and L ij = -a ij , i = j.

Lemma 1 [4]: Zero is an eigenvalue of L with 1 as a right eigenvector and all the nonzero eigenvalues have positive real parts. Zero is a simple eigenvalue of L if and only if G contains a directed spanning tree.

Lemma 2 [34]: Suppose that G is strongly connected. Let r = [r 1 , . . . , r N ] be the positive left eigenvector of L associated with the zero eigenvalue and R = diag(r 1 , . . . , r n ). Then, L RL + L T R is the symmetric Laplacian matrix associated with an undirected connected graph. Let ξ be any vector with positive entries. Then, min ξ T x=0,x =0 (x T Lx/x T x) > (λ 2 ( L)/N), where λ 2 ( L) denotes the smallest nonzero eigenvalue of L.

Lemma 3 [35]: For a nonsingular M-matrix M, there exists a positive diagonal matrix G such that GM + M T G > 0. Moreover, G can be given by diag(g 1 , . . . , g N ), where g = [g 1 , . . . , g N ] T = (M T ) -1 1.

div.head: C. Nonsmooth Analysis
div.p: For a differential equation
where X : R d → R d is measurable but discontinuous, the existence of a continuously differentiable solution is not guaranteed. In this paper, we consider the Filippov solution [36].
div.formula: Definition 1: Let B(R d ) denote the collection of all subsets of R d . The Filippov set-valued map F[X] : R d → B(R d ) is defined by F[X](x) ∩ ς>0 ∩ μ(ς)=0 co X B R d , ς \o , x ∈ R d (2)
div.p: where o is the set of x at which X(x) is discontinuous.
div.formula: B(R d , ς)
div.p: is the open ball of radius ς centered at x, co denotes the convex closure, and ∩ μ(ς)=0 denotes the intersection over all sets o of Lebesgue measure zero.
Definition 2: Filippov solutions are defined to be those absolutely continuous curves satisfying the differential inclusion of the form
The existence of the Filippov solution is ensured by the following lemma.

Lemma 4 [36]: Assume X : R d → R d is measurable and locally essentially bounded, i.e., bounded in any bounded neighborhood of every point of definition excluding the sets of measure zero. Then for all x 0 ∈ R d , there exists a Filippov solution to (1) with the initial condition x(0) = x 0 .
For the Lyapunov analysis of the nonsmooth differentiable equations, we need the following lemma.

Lemma 5 [37]: Let x(•) be a Filippov solution to ẋ(t) = X(x(t)) on an interval containing t, and V : R d → R be a Lipschitz and regular function. Then V(x(t)) is absolutely continuous and (d/dt)V(x(t)) exists almost everywhere
div.formula: d dt V(x(t)) ∈ V(x), for a.e. t ≥ 0 ( 3 ) where V(x) = ∩ ν∈∂V(x(t)) ν T F[X](x). (4

div.head: A. System Model
div.p: In this paper, we consider a set of N identical agents with general linear dynamics. The dynamics of these agents are described as below, similar to [38]
div.formula: ẋi = Ax i + B[u i + ω i ] (5
div.p: in which x i ∈ R n is the state vector, u i ∈ R p is the control input vector, A and B are known constant matrices with compatible dimensions, and ω i ∈ R p denotes external disturbances. For system (5), the following two assumptions are made. Assumption 1: For system ( 5), all the eigenvalues of A are nonzero and have nonpositive real parts. The pair (A, B) is controllable.
Assumption 2: There exists positive constants υ i such that

div.head: B. Triggering Event Design
div.p: In the conventional control protocol, each agent needs to transmit its state signals to its neighbors continuously, which requires a relatively high bandwidth of the communication channel. This is not desirable especially when the network resources are limited. Inspired by [25], we will design an event triggering mechanism for each agent to decide when to transmit its state signals to its neighbors. In this way, continuous communication between different agents is no longer needed, which can largely decrease the consumption of network resources.
To better describe the nature of our proposed event-trigger mechanism, we introduce the state measurement error e i for agent i's state

where {t imk }, imk ∈ z + , m = 1, . . . , n, are the time instants at which the signal transmitting event for agent i's mth state is triggered. Let x im,s denote agent i's mth piecewise constant sampled signal, then the triggering event for agent i's mth state is defined as
div.formula: x im,s (t) = x im (t imk ), t ∈ t imk , t imk+1 ), i = 1, . . . , N(7)
t imk+1 = inf{t ∈ R| |e im (t)| ≥ d im }, m = 1, . . . , n, t im1 = 0 (8)
div.p: where d im is a positive constant denoting the threshold of the triggering event. This triggering event mechanism means that whenever (8) is triggered, the time will be marked as t imk+1 for agent i's mth state and the sampled value x im (t imk+1 ) will be transmitted to its neighbors. During the time t ∈ [t imk , t imk+1 ), the sampled value of x im (t) holds as a constant x im,s (t), i.e., x im,s (t) only needs to be transmitted to its neighbors once in this time interval. Therefore, each agent's state information is broadcast to its neighbors intermittently.

As seen from Fig. 1, each local controller has the following three functions: 1) receives and stores the transmitted signals from its neighbors and itself; 2) computes and updates the control input u i ; and 3) monitors agent i's current state signals x i (t) obtained by the sensors constantly, and then decides whether to transmit them to its neighbors or not. Therefore, similar to the existing results using state-feedback, sensors are used to obtain its state signals for each agent. Then with the state signals obtained, the event-triggering rules ( 6)-( 8), which are implemented by software program, can be evaluated in the local controller. In summary, the implementation and evaluation of our proposed event-triggering rules ( 6)-( 8) in the local controller need no extra hardwares.

div.head: C. Control Objective
div.p: In this paper, we aim to design a control law to make the N agents modeled by (5) achieve consensus under the event triggering mechanism (7) and (8). We will consider two different consensus protocols: one is a leader-follower case in which the graph contains a directed spanning tree with the leader being the root node and the other one is a nonleader case with the communication graph strongly connected. In the following, we will address these two cases separately.

div.head: IV. DISTRIBUTED HIGH-GAIN PROTOCOL FOR LEADER-FOLLOWER GRAPHS
div.p: In this section, we study the leader-follower case. For simplicity, we assume that the agent indexed by 1 is the leader, while the remaining N -1 agents are the followers. Thus, the objective of this section is to propose a distributed consensus protocol under which ||x i (t)x 1 (t)|| (i = 2, . . . , N) is bounded. For the leader, we assume u 1 = 0 and the graph G among the N agents satisfies the following assumption.
Assumption 3: The graph G contains a directed spanning tree with the leader as the root node.

div.head: A. Distributed High Gain Consensus Protocol
div.p: Different from the existing results addressing this problem, we assume that each agent's states are transmitted to its neighbors only when the prefixed events are triggered. The proposed consensus protocol is given as
div.formula: u i = α i Kζ i (i = 2, . . . , N) (9)
div.p: where α i is a positive design constant denoting the controller gain,
div.formula: ζ i = N j=1 a ij (x i,s (t) -x j,s (t)) = N j=1 a ij ⎛ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎝ x i1,s (t) -x j1,s (t) x i2,s (t) -x j2,s (t) . . . x in,s (t) -x jn,s (t) ⎞ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎠ , K = -B T Q with Q > 0
div.p: satisfying the following algebraic Riccati equation:
div.formula: QA + A T Q -QBB T Q + κI = 0 (10
div.p: in which I is a unit matrix, κ and are positive constants specified by the designer. Since the vertex indexed by 1 is the leader and it has no neighbors, the Laplacian matrix L associated with graph G can be written as
div.formula: L = 0 0 1×(N-1) L 2 L 1 . Let ξ = [ξ T 2 , . . . , ξ T N ] T , where ξ i = N j=1 a ij (x i -x j ).
div.p: Then, it follows that:
From ( 5), (9), and (11), we can get
div.formula: ξ = (I N-1 ⊗ A)ξ + L 1 α ⊗ BK ζ + (L 1 ⊗ B) ω(12)
div.p: where
div.formula: ζ = [ζ T 2 , . . . , ζ T N ] T , α = diag(α 2 , . . . , α N ), and ω = [ω T 2 -ω T 1 , . . . , ω T N -ω T 1 ] T . With Definitions 1 and 2, we have ξ ∈ (I N-1 ⊗ A)ξ + L 1 α ⊗ BK F(ζ ) + (L 1 ⊗ B) ω(13)
div.p: where
div.formula: F(ζ ) = [F(ζ 2 ), . . . , F(ζ N )]. Now we need to analyze F(ζ i ) = N j=1 a ij (F(x i,s (t) -F(x j,s (t)), i = 2, . . . , N.
div.p: As can be seen, it is enough to study one entry of F(x i,s (t)) since F(x j,s (t)) has the same properties. Without loss of generality, we consider F(x im,s (t)), m = 1, . . . , n. Note that it is also sufficient to analyze the condition that x im,s (t) > 0, as the same analysis can be repeated for the case that x im,s (t) ≤ 0.
From (8) we know
div.formula: x im -d im ≤ x im,s ≤ x im + d im . (14
div.p: Then for all υ im ∈ F[x im,s (t)], we have
div.formula: x im -d im ≤ υ im ≤ x im + d im (15
div.p: which gives
div.formula: υ im = x im + μ im d im (16
div.p: where μ im can be any number in the set [-1, 1]. Then we obtain
div.formula: F[ζ i ] = N j=1 a ij F x i,s -F x j,s = N j=1 a ij x i + D i -x j -D j = ξ i + χ i (17
div.p: where
div.formula: D i = [u i1 d i1 , . . . , u in d in ] T , with u ip ∈ [-1, 1], p = 1, . . . , n, χ i = N j=1 a ij (D i -D j ). Let χ = [χ T 2 , . . . , χ T N ] T , we have F[ζ ] = ξ + χ. (18
div.p: Substituting ( 18) into (13) gives
Now, we give the following theorem showing the main result of this section.

Theorem 1: Consider system (5) satisfying Assumptions 1-3, and the event-trigger-based control protocol ( 7)-( 9) in which α i > g i , [g 2 , . . . , g N ] T = (L T 1 ) -1 1, G = diag(g 2 , . . . , g N ) and K = -B T Q, Q > 0 is the solution of (10) with 0 < < λ 0 where λ 0 is the smallest eigenvalue of GL 1 + L T 1 G. Then all the followers can track the leader with the tracking error uniformly bounded, and the size of the bound is adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters. Besides, the Zeno behavior is excluded.
Proof: We choose the Lyapunov function as
div.formula: V = N i=2 g i 2 α i ξ T i Qξ i . (20
div.p: By Lemma 4 we have
div.formula: V = N i=2 g i α i ξ T i Q ξi = ξ T αG ⊗ Q (I N-1 ⊗ A)ξ + L 1 α ⊗ BK (ξ + χ ) + ξ T αG ⊗ Q (L 1 ⊗ B) ω = 1 2 ξ T αG ⊗ QA + A T Q + α GL 1 + L T 1 G α ⊗ QBK ξ + ξ T αGL 1 ⊗ QB ω -ξ T αGL 1 α ⊗ QBB T Q χ ≤ 1 2 ξ T αG ⊗ QA + A T Q -λ 0 α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + ξ T αGL 1 ⊗ QB ω -ξ T αGL 1 α ⊗ QBB T Q χ. (21
div.p: Note that
div.formula: ξ T αGL 1 ⊗ QB ω = ξ T σ1 2 α ⊗ QB 2 σ1 GL 1 ⊗ I ω ≤ σ 1 2 ξ T α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 (GL 1 ⊗ I) ω 2 ≤ σ 1 2 ξ T α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (GL 1 ) N i=2 (υ i + υ 1 ) 2(22)
div.p: where σ 1 is a positive constant. Also
div.formula: -ξ T αGL 1 α ⊗ QBB T Q χ = -ξ T σ 2 2 α ⊗ QB 2 σ 2 GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q χ ≤ σ 2 2 ξ T α 2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 2 GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 (23
div.p: where σ 2 is a positive constant.
Choosing 0 < < λ 0 -σ 1 -σ 2 and α i > g i , then substituting ( 22) and ( 23) into (21) gives
div.formula: V ≤ 1 2 ξ T αG ⊗ QA + A T Q -α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (GL 1 ) i=N i=2 (υ i + υ 1 ) 2 + 2 σ 2 GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 ≤ 1 2 ξ T αG ⊗ QA + A T Q -αG ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (GL 1 ) N i=2 (υ i + υ 1 ) 2 + 2 σ 2 GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 ≤ - κ 2 λ min αG ξ 2 + (24
div.p: where 2 and λ min ( αG) is the smallest eigenvalue of αG. By Lemma 4, we know V ≤ -(1/2)κλ min ( αG)||ξ || 2 + . Since χ and υ i , i = 1, . . . , N, are bounded, must be bounded. So we get that the consensus errors ξ are uniformly bounded and the bound is given as
div.formula: = (2/σ 1 )σ max (GL 1 ) N i=2 (υ i + υ 1 ) 2 + (2/σ 2 )||GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q)χ ||
ξ 2 ≤ 4σ max (GL 1 ) σ 1 N i=2 (υ i + υ 1 ) 2 + 4 σ 2 GL 1 α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 κλ min αG . (25
div.p: From ( 25), we can get that by increasing α i at the expense of increasing the control energy, the size of the first part of the numerator in (25), i.e., the effect of the external disturbance, can be reduced. The size of the second part of the numerator can be decreased by decreasing the event triggering threshold d i , at the expense of more triggering events. Besides, it is known that (10) has a unique positive definite symmetric solution Q if (A,B) is controllable [39]. Moreover, Q depends continuously on κ and lim κ↓0 Q = 0, thus the effect of the second part of the numerator in ( 25) is adjustable by adjusting κ. Therefore, the size of the final consensus error bound is adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters. Now, we need to show how the Zeno behavior, i.e., the phenomenon that the event is triggered infinitely times in a finite time interval, can be avoided. This can be done by showing that for each x im (t imk ), i = 1, . . . , N, m = 1, . . . , n, it will take t * im > 0 time units to change from x im (t imk ) to x im (t imk+1 ). To this end, by recalling that e im (t
div.formula: ) = x im (t) -x im (t imk ), ∀t ∈ [t imk , t imk+1 ) we have d dt |e im | = d dt (e im * e im ) 1 2 = sign(e im )ė im ≤ |ẋ im |. (26
div.p: By Assumption 1, we know x i is globally bounded. Since ẋim (t) is continuous function of the system states x i , then there must exist a constant τ im > 0 such that |ẋ im | ≤ τ im . By noting that e im (t imk ) = 0 and lim t→t imk+1 e i (t) = d im , we obtain that the lower bound of interexecution times t * im must satisfy t * im ≥ (d im /τ im ). This completes the proof.

div.head: V. DISTRIBUTED HIGH-GAIN PROTOCOLS FOR STRONG CONNECTED GRAPHS WITH EXTERNAL DISTURBANCES
div.p: In this section, we extend the above results to strongly connected communication graphs where there is no leader. The dynamics of the N agents are the same as (5). In this case, we assume the communication graph satisfies the following assumption.
Assumption 4: The communication graph is strongly connected.
We give the distributed control law as
div.formula: u i = α i Kζ i , i = 1, . . . , N(27)
div.p: where α i , ζ i (i = 1, . . . , N), and K are defined in the same way as the leader-follower case. Let ξ = [ξ T 1 , . . . , ξ T N ] T , where
div.formula: ξ i = N j=1 a ij (x i -x j ), we have ξ = (L ⊗ I n )x. Then, it can be obtained that ξ ∈ (I N ⊗ A)ξ + L α ⊗ BK F(ζ ) + (L ⊗ B)ω (28
div.p: where
div.formula: ζ = [ζ T 1 , . . . , ζ T N ] T , α = diag(α 1 , . . . , α N ) and ω = [ω T 1 , . . . , ω T N ] T .
div.p: Then, by the same analysis in ( 14)-( 18) we have
div.formula: ξ ∈ (I N ⊗ A)ξ + L α ⊗ BK (ξ + χ ) + (L ⊗ B)ω. (29
div.p: Let r = [r 1 , . . . , r N ] T be the positive left eigenvector of L associated with the zero eigenvalue. Define R diag(r 1 , . . . , r N ) > 0 and suppose λ 1 ( L) is the smallest nonzero eigenvalue of L = RL + L T R. Based on (29), we give the following theorem.

Theorem 2: Choose the design parameters as α i > r i and 0 < < (λ 1 ( L)/N) for the distributed controllers (27). Then, under Assumptions 1, 2, and 4, the event-trigger-based control protocol ( 7), (8), and (27) ensures that the tracking errors are uniformly bounded with their bounds adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters and the Zeno behavior is excluded.
Proof: Choose the Lyapunov function as
div.formula: V = N i=1 r i 2 α i ξ T i Qξ i . (30
div.p: Then, we have
div.formula: V = N i=1 r i α i ξ T i Q ξi = ξ T αR ⊗ Q (I N ⊗ A)ξ + L α ⊗ BK (ξ + χ ) + ξ T αR ⊗ Q (L ⊗ B)ω = 1 2 ξ T αR ⊗ QA + A T Q -α L α ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + ξ T αRL ⊗ QB ω -ξ T αRL α ⊗ QBB T Q χ. (31
) Let ξ = ( α ⊗ I n )ξ , then ξ T α-1 r ⊗ I n = ξ T α ⊗ I n α-1 r ⊗ I n = x T L T ⊗ I n (r ⊗ I n ) = x T L T r ⊗ I n = 0 (32
div.p: where we used the fact that r T L = 0. Because α-1 r ⊗ I n is positive, using Lemma 2, we have
div.formula: ξ T L ⊗ I n ξ T > λ 1 L N ξ T ξ = λ 1 L N ξ T α2 ⊗ I n ξ. (33
div.p: Substituting ( 33) into (31) gives
div.formula: V ≤ 1 2 ξ T ⎡ ⎣ αR ⊗ QA + A T Q - λ 1 L N α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ⎤ ⎦ ξ + ξ T αRL ⊗ QB ω -ξ T αRL α ⊗ QBB T Q χ. (34
div.p: Similar to ( 22) and ( 23), we have
div.formula: ξ T αRL ⊗ QB ω = ξ T σ 1 2 α ⊗ QB 2 σ 1 RL ⊗ I ω ≤ σ 1 2 ξ T α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 (RL ⊗ I)ω 2 ≤ σ 1 2 ξ T α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (RL) N i=1 υ 2 i (35
div.p: and
div.formula: -ξ T αRL α ⊗ QBB T Q χ = -ξ T σ 2 2 α ⊗ QB 2 σ 2 RL α ⊗ B T Q χ ≤ σ 2 2 ξ T α2 ⊗ QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 2 R L α ⊗ B T Q χ 2(36)
div.p: where σ 1 and σ 2 are positive constants. Then substituting (35) and ( 36) into (34) gives
div.formula: V ≤ 1 2 ξ T ⎡ ⎣ αR ⊗ ⎛ ⎝ QA + A T Q - ⎛ ⎝ λ 1 L N -σ 1 -σ 2 ⎞ ⎠ QBB T Q ⎤ ⎦ ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (RL) N i=1 (υ i ) 2 + 2 σ 2 R L α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 ≤ 1 2 ξ T αR ⊗ QA + A T Q -QBB T Q ξ + 2 σ 1 σ max (RL) N i=1 υ 2 i + 2 σ 2 RL α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 ≤ - 1 2 κλ min αR ξ 2 +(37)
div.p: where 2 and λ min ( αR) is the smallest eigenvalue of αR. From (37), the consensus error vector ξ is uniformly bounded and the bound is given as
div.formula: = (2/σ 1 )σ max (RL) N i=1 υ 2 i + (2/σ 2 )||RL α ⊗ B T Q)χ ||
ξ 2 ≤ 4 σ 1 σ max (RL) N i=1 υ 2 i + 4 σ 2 RL α ⊗ B T Q χ 2 κλ min αR . (38
div.p: Similar to the analysis in the proof of Theorem 1, the size of the consensus error bound can be reduced by suitably choosing the design parameter α i and κ. Since the eigenvalues of matrix A are nonzero and have no positive real parts, all the states of the N agents are bounded. Thus, by the same analysis in the proof of Theorem 1, the Zeno behavior can be excluded. This complete the proof. Remark 1: Note that [27] proposes an event-based consensus protocol for linear multiagent systems without continuous communication between neighboring agents. However, in [27] the triggering event for each agent depends not only on its own sampled states, but also its neighbors' sampled states as well as the latest control signals. This makes the event triggering mechanism extremely complicated. Besides, whenever the designed event for one agent is triggered, all the states of this agent need to be broadcast to its neighbors. While in this paper, it is seen from ( 7) and ( 8) that each state of an individual agent has one triggering event which only depends on its own signal changing rate, and the agent can transmit its multiple state signals to its neighbors asynchronously. Therefore, our proposed event-based protocols are simpler and more resources-saving in real implementation.

Remark 2: Note that in [27], the final consensus error bound is determined by the threshold of the triggering event. The size of the bound can be only decreased by reducing the threshold, which is at the expense of increasing the number of triggering events (see [27,Remark 3]). In this paper, besides reducing the event threshold, the size of the final consensus error can also be adjusted by suitably choosing the parameters of Riccati equation (10). This will also be illustrated in the simulation example below.

Remark 3: When A has zero or positive eigenvalues, uniformly bounded consensus can still be achieved by following the same procedures of proofs in Theorems 1 and 2. The reason we need Assumption 1 is to exclude the Zeno behavior. Since without this assumption, the consensus trajectory of all the agents may go to infinity which will make the time interval between two triggering events not lower bounded. How to relax Assumption 1 is a challenging topic still under investigation.

div.head: A. Example 1: The Leader-Follower Case
div.p: In this section, we provide a simulation example to illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed control protocol in the leader-follower case by considering the following linear system:

The communication graph is given in Fig. 2, where the vertex indexed by 1 is the leader which is only accessible by agent 2. Clearly, this communication graph satisfies Assumption 3, and we can get [g 1 , g 2 , g 3 ] = [3,4,5]. The leader's initial states are set as [4 5], and the remaining three followers' initial values are all set to be [-5 -6], [- 10 15], and [15 -10], respectively. The disturbances associated with the agents are assumed to be ω 1 = 0, ω 2 = 0.5 * sin(t), ω 3 = 0.8 * sin(t), and ω 4 = 0.4 * cos(2t). To show the size of the tracking error is adjustable by tuning the parameters of the Riccati equation (10) when the event thresholds are fixed, as discussed in Remark 2, we set all the event triggering thresholds as d im = 1, i = 1, 2, 3, 4, m = 1, 2, and the controller gains as α 1 = 4, α 2 = 5, and α 3 = 6. Then we consider the following two pairs of parameters. 2) = 1 and κ = 1. Accordingly, we can get 3 and4 show the trajectories of these four agents, while Figs. 5 and 6 illustrate the actual state signals of agent 1 and the corresponding sampled values transmitted to its followers. Since the remaining three agents broadcast their state information to their neighbors in a similar pattern, they are omitted here. The control signal for the three followers are shown in Figs. 789. From the simulation results, it is observed that uniformly bounded consensus is obtained with our proposed control scheme. Also, the bound of the consensus error is adjustable by choosing suitable design parameters. Note that our proposed event-trigger mechanism only requires each agent to broadcast its information to its neighbors intermittently as shown in Figs. 5 and6. This can largely reduce the communication burden. Clearly, the simulation results verify our theoretical analysis and illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed event-trigger control scheme.

div.head: B. Example 2: The Nonleader Case
div.p: Now, we consider the nonleader case with its application to a class of robots described [40] J qi + Dq i + MgL sin(q i ) = u i + ω i , i = 1, 2, 3, 4 (40) where q i , qi , u i , and ω i are the angle, angular velocity of the rigid link, the control signal and the external disturbances, respectively. J denotes the rotation inertia of the servo motor, D is the damping coefficient, L is the length from the axis of joint to the mass center, M is the mass of the link, and g is the gravitational acceleration. The parameters of system (40) are MgL = 5 and D = 0.002. By neglecting the damping effects and linearizing system (40) around zero, we have where x i1 = q i and x i2 = qi , i = 1, 2, 3, 4. The communication graph of these four robots are given in Fig. 10. Clearly, for system (41), Assumptions 1 and 3 are satisfied. For simulation, the initial conditions for these four agents are set as [1 1], [0 0], [-1 1], and [1 -1], respectively. The external disturbances are assumed to be ω 1 = 0.02 sin(0.5t), ω 2 = 0.05 * sin(t), ω 3 = 0.08 * sin(t), and ω 4 = 0.04 * cos(2t). Then, to design the controller, we set all the event triggering thresholds as Note that, in this simulation example, we apply the control signal obtained from ( 27) to the practical system (40) directly to verify the effectiveness of our proposed control protocol. Fig. 11 shows the state trajectories of these four agents. Note that the actual state signals and their corresponding transmitted values of agent 1 are illustrated in Fig. 12, while the results of agents 2-4 are omitted due to their similarity to those of agent 1. The control signals for these four agents are shown in Figs. 13 and14. Again, the simulation results are consistent with the theoretical analyses which verifies the effectiveness of our proposed control protocol.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we consider the event-based consensus problem for general linear multiagent systems with external disturbances. Two consensus protocols, i.e., the leader-follower case and the nonleader case, are studied separately. An event triggering mechanism for each agent to transmit its state signals to its neighbors is designed, by which continuous communication between the neighboring agents is avoided. To study the discontinuous closed-loop system caused by the event triggering mechanism, nonsmooth analysis techniques including the Filippov solution and differential inclusion are adopted. It is shown that our proposed event-based scheme achieves uniformly bounded consensus. As a future work, it is worthy to explore the tools employed in switched/impulsive systems, such as those in [14] and [17], to consider problems involving event triggered systems, due to their similarities. From 1989 to 1991, he was a Research Associate and then a Post-Doctoral Fellow with the University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA, Australia. Since 1991, he has been with the School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, where he is currently a Full Professor. His current research interests include control systems and applications, intelligent power management system, smart grids, cyber-physical systems, complex systems and networks, model-based online learning and system identification, and signal and image processing.

figure.head: Lantao
figure.figDesc: Xing received the bachelor's degree in automation engineering from the China University of Petroleum, Beijing, China, in 2009. He is currently pursing the Ph.D. degree in control science and engineering with Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China. His current research interests include nonlinear systems, multiagent systems, and quantized and adaptive control. Changyun Wen (F'10) received the B.Eng. degree from Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China, in 1983 and the Ph.D. degree from the University of Newcastle, Callaghan, NSW, Australia, in 1990.

Dr. Wen is an Associate Editor of a number of journals including Automatica, the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONICS, and the IEEE Control Systems Magazine. He is an Executive Editor-in-Chief for the Journal of Control and Decision. From 2000 to 2002, He served as an Associate Editor of the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON AUTOMATIC CONTROL. He has been actively involved in organizing international conferences playing the roles of the General Chair, the General Co-Chair, the Technical Program Committee Chair, the Program Committee Member, the General Advisor, and the Publicity Chair. He was a recipient of the Institution of Engineers, Singapore Prestigious Engineering Achievement Award 2005. He is a member of the IEEE Fellow Committee from 2011 to 2013 and a Distinguished Lecturer of the IEEE Control Systems Society from 2010 to 2013.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the China Scholarship Council, in part by the 111 Project under Grant B07031, in part by the National Nature Science of China under Grant 61134007, Grant 61223004, and Grant 61433013, in part by the Public Projects of Zhejiang Province under Grant 2015C31124. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor G.-P. Liu.
